awd_titl_txt: New Multifunctional Transition Metal Oxides with Correlated Electronic Properties
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Abstract
With support from the Solid State and Materials Chemistry program in the Division of Materials Research, the focus of this research is the synthesis and characterization of new transition metal oxides with low-dimensional, strongly interacting electronic properties to discover new multifunctional polar and magnetic electronic materials with fundamentally important and technologically useful behavior. The emphasis of the program is the detailed characterization of the structure and physical properties to understand the structure-property relationships. It has been demonstrated repeatedly that fundamental research of this type provides the basis for discovering new materials, which lead to novel phenomena and useful applications. The proposed work will impact the training and education of Postdoctoral fellows, graduate and undergraduate students in the PI's laboratory in the experimental synthesis and characterization of new functional solid state materials. Collaborative work of the PI with other scientists and condensed matter theorists nationally and internationally provides additional broader impact for the scientific training and education of students. These studies are expected to yield not only critical insight for the control of the properties of novel electronic and magnetic materials, but also to provide broader impacts for potential applications of the discovered materials in microelectronics and magneto-electronics for computers, sensors and communications. These are critical areas for maintaining US technological leadership worldwide. 

Technical Abstract
The focus of the experimental program is the synthesis and characterization of new functional transition metal compounds with strongly correlated electronic properties that are on the verge of electronic and structural instabilities, and to fine-tune the competing electronic interactions through the unstable region in a controlled way. Experience shows that materials with novel behavior are likely to be discovered, when lattice, spin, charge, orbital and other electronic interactions compete. Such competing interactions can lead to interesting and useful properties, including metal-to-insulator transition, magnetic ordering, spin and charge density wave instabilities, multiferroic, magnetoelectric behavior and superconductivity. In low-dimensional materials the interplay of competing interactions is enhanced. Systems of interest include: (1) Transition metal Ruddlesden-Popper (RP) layered phases, AO(ABO)n; (2) Layered double perovskites, AA'BB'O6; (3) Quadruple perovskites AA'3B4O12; (4) AA'BB' O6 new non-centrosymmetric corundum phases. These complex, strongly correlated electronic materials share the common feature of an interplay between localized and itinerant degrees of freedom, a highly variable conduction electron band-width, which may be tuned by changing e.g., the crystal structure, chemical composition, external strain and degree of disorder. The variability of band-width leads to a variety of important phenomena, including metal-insulator transitions (or sharp crossovers) driven by variation of temperature, magnetic field, illumination, pressure, lattice distortion and other variables. We expect that in the vicinity of these transitions the transport, electronic and magnetic properties will also change dramatically and will be tunable. The effort is a systematic study of unique synthetic routes including solid state, high pressure, "chemo douche" hydrothermal for the stabilization of new and interesting transition metal compounds. Crystal growth (essential to study anisotropic properties) of promising new phases will be attempted by e.g., flux growth, chemical vapor transport, and electrolysis. The characterization of properties by a battery of physical measurements including x-ray and neutron diffraction, electron diffraction and transmission electron microscopy, temperature dependent transport, specific heat, dielectric and magnetic properties measurements will be carried out.

por.por_cntn:
The synthesis and characterization of new transition metal oxides including Ruddlesden-Popper, double and quadruple perovskites, and corundum-derived polar magnetic phases with strongly correlated electronic interactions were undertaken to discover new multifunctional materials with fundamentally important and technologically useful properties. The research undertook a systematic study of unique synthetic routes such as high pressure (3-8 GPa) and high temperature (700 – 1500 °C) methods to stabilize new solid state transition metal compounds. Single crystal growth of new phases was undertaken for the characterization of directional properties in detail by diverse physical properties measurements, including temperature dependent x-ray, neutron and electron diffraction, high resolution transmission electron atomic imaging, magnetic and resistivity measurements, x-ray absorption spectroscopy and others. The focus of the research was the understanding and control of the structure-properties relationships. We have demonstrated that this type of fundamental research provides the basis for discovering new materials with novel phenomena and useful applications.

The new functional transition metal compounds synthesized with strongly interacting electronic properties near electronic and structural instabilities were fine-tuned through the competing interactions by changing for example the crystal structure, chemical composition, external strain and degree of disorder in a controlled way, to yield the desired and useful properties. In this way, we discovered new materials with competing lattice, spin, charge, orbital electronic interactions and, as expected interesting and useful properties, including metal-to-insulator transition, magnetic ordering, spin and charge density wave instabilities, multiferroic/magnetoelectric behavior and superconductivity. In the quasi - low-dimensional materials we studied, the interplay of competing interactions is enhanced to facilitate the discovery of new phenomena.

The major structural systems we investigated were the perovskites (ABO3, A = Group I,II elements of the Periodic Table; B = 3d, 4d, 5d, transition metals, e.g., Co, Ru, Re ) double perovskites (AA’BB’O6, A/A’ and B/B’ similar as in ABO3) and AA’BB’O6 new noncentrosymmetric corundum phases with A and A’ small transition (e.g., Mn2+) or main group metal ions (e.g., Zn2+); B/B’ is a 3d, 4d, or 5d transition metal ion (e.g., Fe3+, Mo5/6+, Re5/6+).

The NSF supported work from 2015– 2019  (NSF-DMR - 1507252 ) resulted in 47 publications in high impact scientific journals, including Science Advances, Material Advances, Angewandte Chemistry, Int. Edition, J. American Chemical Society, etc. Highlights of the research results obtained are: confirmation of magnetostriction-polarization coupling in multiferroic Mn2MnWO6 and in AMn2O5­  with A = rare earth ion including Nd, Gd, Tb, Dy; several ABO3 and A2BB’O6 phases with above room temperature magnetic order and magneto resistance. Our single crystals of one-dimensional superconducting Li0.9MoO6O17 have been used by several physics groups worldwide, and specifically by a UK physics group (Prof, Hussey at University of Bristol) who demonstrated the exotic phenomena of spin and charge separation for the first time experimentally in Li0.9MoO6O17 - the possibility of which was predicted theoretically in the past by Tomonaga and Luttinger theoretically.

        Broader impacts of the NSF supported work include the training and education of several Postdoctoral Fellows, graduate and undergraduate students in the experimental synthesis and characterization of new functional solid-state materials in the PI’s laboratory, which are essential to meet the technological challenges of the twenty first century. Moreover, collaborative work of the PI with other scientists and condensed matter theorists who are well established nationally and internationally, provided additional broader impact for the scientific training and education of students who participated in the research. The studies yielded not only critical understanding and insight for the synthesis, control of the properties of new electronic and magnetic materials, but also to provide broader impacts for potential applications of the discovered materials in microelectronics and magneto-electronics including computers, sensors and communications. These are critical areas for maintaining US technological leadership worldwide. Sharing of single crystals and the new material products of the work with the broad scientific community for further investigations afford additional impact.
